name: Nagarjuna
shortDescription: Founder of Madhyamaka philosophy who retrieved Prajnaparamita sutras from the nagas, revered as 'Second Buddha'
longDescription: Nagarjuna (c. 150-250 CE) is one of the most important philosophers in Buddhist history, founding the Madhyamaka (Middle Way) school that became the philosophical foundation of Mahayana Buddhism. His name 'Naga-arjuna' means 'noble serpent,' derived from the legend of his encounter with the nagas (serpent deities) who invited him to their underwater palace and presented him with the Prajnaparamita Sutras (Perfection of Wisdom texts), which the Buddha had taught but the world was not ready to receive. Born to a Brahmin family in South India, he mastered the entire Tripitaka in 90 days. His revolutionary teachings on emptiness (shunyata) and masterwork Mulamadhyamakakarika profoundly influenced all subsequent Buddhist thought. He served as abbot of Nalanda monastery, advisor to kings, and was also known as an alchemist. According to legend, he achieved immortality through alchemy and meditation but compassionately offered his life when a prince's destiny required it, being killed only by kusha grass‚Äîthe one substance that could harm him. Considered an emanation of Manjushri, he is revered as the 'Second Buddha' for reviving and clarifying the Buddha's teachings.

biography.earlyLife: Mastered Vedas and sciences, learned invisibility technique, entered king's harem with friends. After friends were executed, realized lust leads to suffering and became a Buddhist monk.
biography.education: Memorized entire Tripitaka (Buddhist canon) in 90 days

majorEvents.description: Invited to underwater naga palace, received Prajnaparamita Sutras that Buddha had taught but world wasn't ready for
Became abbot of great monastery at Nalanda, center of Buddhist learning
Served as spiritual advisor to Satavahana king, emptied royal treasury to feed poor during famine
Defeated non-Buddhist scholars in debate, converting them to Dharma
Achieved immortality through alchemy but offered life to prince whose destiny required it; killed only by kusha grass, the one substance that could harm him

achievements: Established emptiness (shunyata) as central Mahayana doctrine
Developed Two Truths doctrine (conventional and ultimate reality)
Served as abbot of Nalanda monastery
Practiced and taught alchemy and medicine
biography.legacy: Revered as 'Second Buddha' for clarifying Buddha's teachings. Prophecies state he will be reborn as chief disciple of future Buddha Maitreya. His philosophy became foundation of all Mahayana and Vajrayana schools.

coreConcepts.name: Emptiness (Shunyata)
coreConcepts.description: All phenomena lack inherent existence, arising only through dependent origination

coreConcepts.name: Two Truths
coreConcepts.description: Conventional truth (everyday reality) and ultimate truth (emptiness), both valid in their sphere

coreConcepts.name: Tetralemma (Catuskoti)
coreConcepts.description: Four-fold negation: things neither exist, nor not exist, nor both, nor neither

coreConcepts.name: Dependent Origination
coreConcepts.description: All things arise in dependence on causes and conditions, nothing is independent

coreConcepts.name: Middle Way
coreConcepts.description: Avoiding extremes of eternalism (things permanently exist) and nihilism (nothing exists)
